39334103.review:
Catlateral Damage is, on the surface, a game about a cat knocking things over. I purchased it as sort of a "hey, this looks like a cute game to waste a couple hours on," but it very quickly grew on me as something much more. With bonus levels, unlockable cats, a collection book for us completionists, events, and Easter Eggs, Catateral Damage has proven itself to be so much more.

It's a bit reminiscent of the Katamari series, with the general gameplay being item collection in a human's world, but the differences end there. It's story telling capabilities aren't on Katamari's level - your cat does, however, sometimes wake up with different reasons to ruin the human's day, but it doesn't go much deeper. It doesn't really need to, though. The different events and things you come across in the world are enough to keep you interested.

While it has no true multiplayer, I've booted it up with friends over and have had great positive feedback. We play Objective mode and pass the controller around after each level. It's not 100% fair, as the time limit on each level varies, but you are guaranteed 4 levels (sometimes more, if you find bonus worlds).

I can see SO much potential for Catlateral Damage's future, and I hope the Devs have plans for an update, or even a Catlateral Damage 2. I would love to see more worlds/items (maybe some a bit more fantastical/colorful), different variations of unlockable cats, and a true incorporated co-op multiplayer.

Definitely worth picking up at full price, and even better if you manage to catch it on sale.

39220847.review: Possibly the most advanced cat sim on Steam.  Works well with my Logitech Pawmaster P-270, though the FFB needs a bit of tweaking on the paw thrust maneuvers.  The laser-scanned locals are well represented and the physics modeling is top notch.  Still accessible for the genre newcomer, though hardcore catsim professionals may want to stick with the more in-depth "Shelter" series.

39216435.review:
Catlateral Damage is a game of missed opportunities.

It could have been so much more: a game in which you play as a cat that wants to wreck as many things in the house as possible. Will you be chasing mice around the home? How much havoc will you wreck while trying to complete your objectives?

Unfortunately, the game doesn't know what to do with its premise. It is actually about clicking left to swipe with your left paw and clicking right to swipe with your right paw. The objectives mode is literally: swipe stuff to the floor for five minutes and then do it again and again and again.

There is an upgrade system, but it only affects swiping speed, movement speed and jumping height. It only serves to distract you from the main objective, which may be for the best, seeing as that is not super interesting.

Don't get me wrong: I'm happy that this game exists and I do not regret backing this project as a Kickstarter. But it could have been *so* much more.

38586816.review:
【ゲーム内容】
猫になって破壊の限りを尽くすゲーム。物を落とす（壊す）ことで得点が入る。
制限時間内にステージごとに決められた個数物を落とす目標アリモードと，ステージ内を自由に探索（破壊）できる猫砂ボックスモードがある。
トイレットペーパーを出しまくったり，観葉植物を殴り続けたり，おもちゃで遊んだりするとプレゼント箱が落ちてくる。破壊するとグレードアップし，ネコパンチの威力，ジャンプ力，走るスピードを上げることができる。
最大限まで強化された猫は，観葉植物はおろか大型テレビを一撃で吹き飛ばし，部屋の端から端までひとっとび，最終ステージのそこそこ広い部屋を十数秒で駆け回る化け猫と化す。
……要するにストレス解消ゲー。

【良い点】
[b]単純に面白い。猫可愛い。[/b]1回1回が短いので気軽に遊べる。収集要素が多い（落とした物，写真，実績など）上，[b]ステージは毎回ランダム生成（ある程度家のテーマは決まっている）のため，繰り返し遊んでもストレスなしで新鮮。[/b]小ネタ有り。そして，実は[b]良BGM。[/b]
安い。日本語対応。トレカ・実績対応。

【悪い点】
[b]画面が超激しく動く。猫だし。酔う人は酔うと思う。[/b]特にVRでやったりなんかしたら。

【総評】
買って損はない。どちらかというとミニゲーム系だが，飽きのこないゲームだ。セール時にサウンドトラックも併せてワンコイン以下になるので，とりあえず買ってみても良い。

38258259.review:
Catlateral Damage (pun intended) is a little cat game that I can recommend to all cat lovers who like first person (or should I say "first purrson") games. 

It's not really a simulator. It's a first person action game with a cat. You have to jump and drop things on the floor, catch mice and laser dots. Most time you have to destroy things in a flat or a house (with different rooms). But there are bonus levels (like a Mewseum, a supermarket or a laboratory).

The levels are generated randomly. Also the number of things to drop down and the time limit is set randomly. That means it's sometimes too hard and sometimes too easy. But most times it's all fine.

The controls (mouse and keyboard) work fine. The tutoriral explains it very well. It also has nice comic graphics and really happy music. The music supports the game perfectly. It's never annoying. Playing this game can bring you in a happy mood.

If you have seen all levels there are still some challenges left. Getting all the achievements and pictures of cats will make you play the game again and again. There's only one thing to be critizised: most of the time you run, jump and throw things on the floor. That can become annoying.

pros:
- you play a cat
- OMG! You play a CAT!
- nice graphics
- happy mewsic
- random levels
- additional challanges (achievements and collectibles)
- hidden references (movies and games)

cons:
- random levels
- most of the time you only drop things down
- no interaction with other cats or humans
- no high score list (only one score saved for every mode)

I can recommend this game to cat lovers and all people who ever wanted to play as a cat in first purrson purrspective. It's not a game you would play 100 hours ore more. But the hours you play you'll have much fun with it.

36227370.review:
Original URL : http://www.htcvivegamereviews.com/all-review-list/send-one-vet-catlateral-damage-review/
Original Let's Play(1 level) : http://www.htcvivegamereviews.com/all-video-list/think-need-catnip-catlateral-damage/

4/10

So I grabbed this game after playing the first couple levels of Kittypocalypse – perhaps I was on a subconscious cat game fix. The concept of Catlateral Damage is basically you’re a cat with the task of destroying as many as your owner’s precious possessions before the timer runs out. The game boasts a randomized room system which means no two playthroughs are the same. I don’t doubt this but I do doubt the replayability nonetheless.

The weakness to me of the game is the lack of direction. Although destroying things can be fun – there isn’t much satisfaction in doing so. I am told there is collectibles and other goodies to find such as powerups but they alluded me in my playthrough and I did not notice any. “Objective mode” had absolutely no difference to me than “Litter Box mode” from what I could see. I was told no instructions nor any pop-up menus explaining any other nuances to the game so I assumed there wasn’t any.

Graphically and audio wise – the game looks good. The cartoonish/cute world fits well with the theme of the game. The sounds of a cat gets old but what do you expect in a game in which you play a cat. The different cats you can “play as” change your paw colors which is a nice addition.

For $9.99, it’s a mixed sell to me. Although I can see this being great for maybe a younger audience or far more casual gamers than myself – most serious gamers won’t bother with this more than once. I admit – I am likely not the target audience but I was interested in the “small perspective” mode after enjoying games like Toy Commander for the Sega Dreamcast. The question it comes down to – if you’re buying this game for someone younger, it might be a decent buy. If you’re buying it for a random destruction game – I feel like there is better choices at better prices. It just feels too simplistic to me at the moment for $9.99.

[b]Motion sickness[/b] (I usually don't get motion sickness while playing. See more below)

Download and play Creativerse (it's free):

31514347.review:
Catlateral Damage is a fun, cute and very addictive game which helps relieve stress and brings out your inner kitty :3 you play as a cat (there are many to choose from which you can unlock) and the aim of the game is to knock over as many of your owner(s)' possesions as possible and to make the house as messy as can be before the time runs out. The objects you knock down count as points and for each level there's a certain amount of points you need to get before the time runs out; there are also certain items you can knock down and collect - which vary from level to level - that earn you more points so you can complete your objective quicker. Upgrades are available as well which increase things like your speed, your swat strength and your jump so as you progress it's easier to tackle the increasingly difficult objectives.

There are two game modes: Objective Mode (the main mode I just explained) and Litterbox Mode. Litterbox Mode is a Sandbox Mode where you can knock down as much as you like with no time limit! You can choose your location and spend hours as a destructive kitty ^w^

The characters are very cute and the music only adds to the fun and optimistic environment; overall a very entertaining game which is easy to spend hours upon hours on :D
As for the price? For $11.99 I'd say it's certainly worth it as there are a lot of things to unlock and find, the achievements are rewarding and there's a large variety of levels and locations. It's also a wonderful gift :) though if you're patient enough to wait until Catlateral Damage is on sale, it's your choice and I hope you have fun playing it if you do have it OwO

I really like this game and recommend it to those who love cute and happy things, and love to cause a bit of a ruckus in-game. It's surprisingly a really good stress releiver so if you're feeling a bit frustrated this game really cheers you up ^-^


Thank you so much for reading my review and I hoped it helped you out :3c
~ Pet

28131875.review:
Catlateral damage is a short, sweet, and to-the-point game - you're a cat with two paws and a mouth with which to wreak havoc around your absentee owner's dwelling. Your motives for doing this are announced in the beginning of each level, and are appropriately catty, including such gems as "My wet food tastes terrible! Those humans will pay!"

You're offered two modes of play - Objective and Litterbox. Objective Mode throws you a timer and a certain amount of objects to topple; a single campaign requiring a player to complete 5 objectives - or 5 houses - successfully before the time runs out. You can additionally play with "cat toys" (put in quotes because some of these include scratching posts and litterboxes; others are houseplants and toilet paper, which many people do not consider conventional toys for their feline) to earn power-ups that can make you jump higher, move faster, and swipe at objects harder. You're also encouraged to collect cat photos, as doing so unlocks new cats to play as and two achievements! 

Litterbox Mode, meanwhile, sets you loose in any house you desire to destroy stuff at your leisure. 

Both modes are subject to randomized "events" that occur; these vary vastly, from "Moon Gravity" and "Disco" to "Kill the red dots" and "Catch the mouse". Every house is also proceedurally-generated, so there are different objects to wreck every time you play, although the layout of the furniture, as far as I can tell, stays the same. My only beef with the game is that there isn't more of it; there're only a handful of houses to run amok in currently, with four or so interesting add-ons, like the Mewseum and Supermarcat. The game is fun, but since it's so small, that can only go so far; if you're not very bored and very into cats and/or pure destruction, this probably isn't the game for you. 

TL;DR: This game is so good; the purest cat game you will ever get your hands on. Would probably wait for it to go on sale, though. 9/10

Motion-sickness motion-sickness motion-sickness oh my god the motion-sickness is unbearable in this game. 

I have NEVER experienced motion-sickness in a game before, but this game really did it for me. It's fine to play for 5-10 minutes at a time, but if I play any longer than that I feel extremely nauseous to the point to where I feel like vomiting, and that feeling would stick with me for a good half an hour. Now, since I've never experienced motion-sickness before playing this game I would've let it slide if the devs would've at least MENTIONED the possibility of motion-sickness, but it seems like they haven't done so. Apparently many people experienced this problem, but the devs never acknowledged this issue and it's not likely they ever will..

It's such a shame too because this game is cute and a great time-killer, but it is IMPOSSIBLE to play for more than 10 minutes at a time, and the achievements are relatively easy to get so I've been willing to do just that, but it is extremely annoying. PLEASE fix this if this is an issue that can be fixed or at least mention it somewhere before purchasing so that those who are prone to motion-sickness, or those who don't know yet, at least acknowledge what they're getting themselves into.

Again, it is an okay game, but a nice warning before purchasing the game would've been nice. :/

24686674.review:
Published by: Chris Chung
Developed by: Chris Chung, Fire Hose Games 
Genre: Simulator, Indie, Casual
Release Date: 27 May, 2015
Time to complete: 10+ hours

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Swipe and push all your human’s belongings to the floor in this first-person cat destruction simulator.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Have you ever aspired to be a troublemaking cat? Well now you can fulfil your desires! Catlateral Damage is a casual first-person cat simulator in which your sole purpose is to cause mass destruction to your owner’s home. Swipe books off shelves, plates out of cupboards and saucepans off stove tops! You are also able to swipe at portraits which, when knocked down, unlocks the image to view in the collections folder in the menu. You’re able to unlock over 230 strange and wonderful varieties of animal photos, including (and my personal favourite thus far) a very solemn looking black dog wearing a cat birthday hat (what more could you want, right?)!
There are two game modes; Objective and Litterbox. In Objective mode, you have to knock down a certain number of objects within a time limit in a procedurally-generated house. Litterbox mode is slightly more relaxed; You have to knock down every object in the map that you get to choose (you can unlock more as you go along), but there is no time limit. My personal favourite is what I like to call ‘Bah Humbug mode’, where you get to rip open and destroy presents, knock over festive decorations and swipe all the ornaments off the Christmas tree! Wooh!
The game has unlockables, events and power-ups, including increased swipe, increased jump and increased speed. There is also a catnip unlockable which slightly distorts your vision and effortlessly enables you to swipe entire plates off a shelf with one brisk movement!
Some of the events include moon gravity (did someone say floating cat?!) and disco, which turns the house into the ultimate par-tay destination!
You are also able to chase mice and lasers, which is oddly satisfying!

[h1]Replay Value[/h1]
There are many different levels to play in Litterbox mode, providing hours of fun and destruction! Even after you’ve completed them all, it’s still a game I think you would easily open up again once in a while, as it really does provide plenty of amusement and entertainment.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
The music throughout the game is very upbeat, but is very repetitive and can get pretty annoying after a while. Audio controls are your friend.

[h1]Overall Verdict[/h1]
Catlateral Damage is a very amusing game, and I can’t help but get the urge to play it every now and again. It’s also very decently priced considering the amount of gameplay available.
Seriously, you don’t know how much fun breaking things can be until you’ve played this game. I now finally understand my cats.

[h1]Overall Score: 7/10[/h1]

23965254.review:
First of all, I wanted to thank the developers for creating such an amazing game, and now let's get into it!
If you REALLY love cats then look no further! Catlateral Damage is the perfect game for you, my dear cat lover friend!

The game's been created by Chris Chung in honour of his cat Nippy (1997-2014), and thanks to him we, you can now play as one of those furious cats whose owners made the mistake of leaving them home alone.
And as I said, they're no normal cats! They were just waiting for the right moment to go on a rampage and knock everything they can knock onto the floor, that meaning all they can find, leaving nothing but a huge mess behind them... and imagine when the owner comes back home and finds his house completely messed up, everything's on the floor, something's even broken and his cat's quietly spleeping in his box... that would drive each and everyone of us crazy, wouldn't it?
And that's exactly what YOU have to do! In this awesome first-person cat simulator you play as a cute kitten whose objective is to knock as much as possible right onto the floor, leaving a mess your owner is then supposed to clean up. Forget you're a human! You're cat now! You'll see the world from the perspective of a cat, you'll walk, jump, crouch, think and act like an annoying (but cute!) little kitten whose weapons are his paws, his little mouth and his furry soft body. Aside the main task you'll have to complete to complete the level, under the quest are shown two objects: the one on the left gives extra points when knocked onto the ground, while the right one will give you a free upgrade when a certain amount of it will be destroyed by your little paws.
In the levels there are games you can play with to obtain a perk for one of the three categories, which are jump, speed and swat. There are also events, such as free upgrades, glowing red dots, mice, disco, moon gravity, force shield and power outage. 
Oh, and don't forget about those 267 (have fun ^.^) photos you can find while running through the levels, remember to knock them off the walls or the shelves in order to unlock them. Those photos portrait cats, dogs, and a few other house pets.

There are two game modes you can play: Objective Mode and Litterbox Mode:
-In Objective mode you're given an amount of time and a definite number of things (such as 190 objects in 5 minutes) you'll have to knock onto the ground before the time runs out. Every game is composed of five levels during which you'll be given different tasks and optional objectives and.. don't tell anyone, but you can also find a christmas tree that will lead you to a special christmas-themed level, a tyrannosaurus that will lead you to the Mewseum where you'll have to destroy objects worth a certain amount of dollars, a shopping cart that will lead you to the Supermarkat where you'll have to destroy a couple of specific products, some kind of cat boxes that will lead you to the Cardboard Box Paradise and finally an object I haven't manage to unlock yet that will lead you straight to the Furightful Lab.

- Litterbox Mode is quite different, you don't have time nor an amount of things to destroy, your box is already open, what you're supposed to do here is to knock onto the floor what you want to and then leave whenever you want. In this mode you can select the level you want to play and there'll be no events (I'm an idiot, there ARE events!), you can take all the time you want, no one's telling you to hurry, just: relax, take it eeeaaasy! (I love Mika ^.^)

You may be concerned there aren't a lot of levels and it's true, but! they change every time due to the procedural generation of the levels. You surely will play the same level multiple times but it will always have something different since last time you played it. Anyway what I liked the most about this game is the soundtrack. That has to be said, it's just f*cking awesome! You have to love it! It is at your side for all the time you'll be playing, it never bores you and what about those meows you can hear by pressing F? Ahhh so sweet, as soon as I'm done I'm going to pet my little Kitten. The cartoon-based graphic? Lovely, it really fits the game, you don't need anything too sophisticated to make a wonderful game and Catlateral Damage IS a wonderful game!
Ok.. I'm tired.. I've been writing for more than an hour.. you know what? I'm almost done, and I also believe you're tired of me already... ok let's end this.

Just buy and enjoy this awesome game.
End of the story. Cheers!!
//Drak

Quem já perdeu um animal de estimação sabe que um pedaço da alma vai embora junto com ele, e a maneira que o criador teve de manter a memória de Nippy viva, foi colocá-lo como o gato principal do jogo. Isso é espetacular.

Eu não tenho nenhuma visão negativa do jogo, principalmente porque o vejo como homenagem a Nippy. E uma das mais lindas que já vi.

Conclusão: 
- Comprei para me divertir com um jogo simples, fui pego de surpresa por todos esses sentimentos.

- 10/10

R.I.P. Nippy.

[Review in EN]

The final game for those who love and live with cats.

I usually do not do any kind of review, but this game in particular caught my attention for a few reasons:

- Cat Simulator with the primary mission of cats on this planet: destroy things at will.
- Extremely fun and relaxing. Activate the game, break things, be instantly happy.
- Several cat types, you can play with the doppelgänger of destructive hairy ball that you have in your home.

And the main reason:

After reading the credits (What guarantees an achievement Steam, be smart!), I realized that the game was made in honor of the game's creator cat named Nippy, who died in 2014. After reading the credits, you will find a picture of them with the words "In loving memory of Nippy (1997-2014).. A wonderful friend & companion"

Anyone who has lost a pet knows that a piece of the soul goes away with him, and the way that the creator had to keep the memory alive Nippy, has put it as the main game cat. This is spectacular.

I have no negative view of the game, mainly because I see it as a tribute to Nippy. And one of the most beautiful I've ever seen.

Conclusion:
- I got to have fun with a simple game, I was taken aback by all those feelings.

- 10/10

R.I.P. Nippy.

身为猫奴，国外游戏开发者 Chris Chung 却从他养了 17 年的猫那里得到灵感，为猫奴们量身打造了一款 VR 模拟类游戏——《Catlateral Damage》，名字灵感来源于电影《Collateral damage》（间接伤害），简直道出了猫奴的心声！

角色扮演：你在游戏里扮演一只横冲直撞的猫，以猫的视角看世界，走、环顾四周、跳、蹲。

游戏得分：看你弄掉物体的大小和连续数目，只要在指定时间内达到标准分数就算过关。

游戏场景：客厅、浴室、厨房、超市、博物馆等。

随着通关越多，可以解锁不同的猫。

游戏中最初猫的原型基于现实中的淘气猫，开发者 Chris Chung 把童年陪伴他长大的小黑猫 Nippy 高度还原到游戏中。也就是最开始那一只！

如果你是猫奴，想翻身农民把歌唱，那么这款游戏适合你【微笑】！

23381767.review:
This game is exactly what you think it is. If the idea of playing as a cat and knocking things on the floor doesn't appeal to you, don't expect anything more here. Sure, there are things to unlock, half a dozen levels, and a get-the-laser minigame, but at the end of the day you're just a cat pushing cel-shaded objects on the floor.

The game's Objective mode can be frustrating but is almost always fair, where you knock down a certain number of objects in either way too little or way too much time; the different time limts set a good overall pace where you don't have to be entirely frantic or bored the whole time. Sandbox mode is pretty much exactly what you'd expect, although perfectionists ought to be careful here as it can be difficult if not impossible to "complete" certain levels as there is zero leeway regarding object count and sometimes an object that has fallen on another object will not count toward your total. Although you can collect power-ups in both modes, they are not persistent except immediately between levels in the objective mode, so consider yourself starting from scratch in each session.

I really like the collectibles aspect, where a list of everything you've encountered is archived and separated by item type. It would have been nice if you could interact with the objects in this list to view their models, or at least if they were named, but it gives a little more depth to an otherwise simple game.

Catlateral Damage is the kind of game you dip into and then out of. Start it, play it for a few minutes, quit. That's it.

There isn't much to sink your teeth into, but nor is there much to complain about. You play as a cat. As that cat, you smack stuff with your paws and reduce a room to rubble. As said above, that's it. That's all there is.

But. 

If you're the kind of person who takes time off from their cat-related subreddit to post on their cat-related tumblr while pushing their actual cat off their keyboard, you might find this game more enchanting. There are many cats to choose from. You get to do cat-ish things like being a dick to your owner's possessions. You can sit in a box.

Thrilling stuff.

To conclude: if you range from contemptuous to ambivalent about cats, you'll find some vague amusement from this game. Buy it when it's cheap. If you've got an unironic cat-themed sweater and a mug that says, "Cats are purrrfect," you're gonna shit yourself.

Sous ces faux airs de "blague" [u][i]CatLateral Damage[/i][/u] s'avère en réalité être un jeu original, drôle et très amusant. En effet même si l'idée de contrôler un chat qui envole tout sur son passage est très basique et assez farfelue elle n'est pas moins fonctionnel, dés les premiers instants le jeu est très amusant et on prend un plaisir fou à détruire tout ce que l'on peut. 

Il s'agit littéralement d'un jeu où le seul but est de s'amuser à foutre le bordel, et c'est cool ! Honnêtement le seul point faible du jeu c'est qu'il est tellement répétitif qu'il est difficile d'y jouer très longtemps sans en être totalement lassé. La seule chose qui peut éventuellement vous donnez l'envie d'y jouer plus qu'une heure ou deux c'est de débloquer les succès que le jeu propose, autrement il n'y a pas vraiment de quoi s'éterniser dessus.

Bref pour moi ce titre est vraiment une bonne pioche, c'est très sympa et puis c'est différent des autres jeux. Cependant je ne recommande pas d'en faire l’acquisition au prix fort ( 9,99€ ) car sincèrement rien ne justifie un tel tarif. (2/25/2016) after some thinking...

Steam really needs a ~ (mixed) button for these reviews. I like this game, a lot, I really do, but in its current state and at its current price I just can't fully recommend it. I bought it because I saw JoshJepson play it on YouTube, and it looked like fun... and it is! It really is! But it's just not enough fun and it's definitely not with $10! Thankfully I got it on a 50% off sale... but I still even hesitate to say it's worth $5. With the small amount of content and replayability it has now it's maybe worth $3.

What would make it better, and push me to fully recommend it, is if it had more levels, with more objects and special elements, and more cats and maybe if the cats had different special abilities. Most of the varying events that happen and achievements things that you can unlock have little effect on the gameplay and are not very rewarding. Also, another big thing it's missing for me is multiplayer. I would love to be able to play in a map with friends playing other cats helping me knock stuff over, or in a race to see who can destroy the most stuff or whatever.

So in short -

+ fun-sounding music
+ fun idea
+ fun to be a cat
+ fun!

- the fun gets old fast
- not enough content to be worth the price
- different cats have no special abilities
- not much variation in gameplay
- no multiplayer

If you really want it, get it on a sale. If the developer ever gives it a big update with more stuff, I might update this review.

[i]Catlateral Damage[/i] has a cartoony art style but it's not a gimmick--it's clearly crafted with care and attention to feedback.  This is a game that has a Disco Mode... and also has an option on the menu to [i]entirely disable Disco mode forever.[/i]

The main, timed game is cleverly self-limiting--four timed trials with potential unlock of a special level--so you have a good stopping point and might not end up swatting things off shelves all day.

As an extremely casual gamer, one of my criteria is whether a game lets you unlock photos of the devs' kitties. This one does, as well as real cat-based alternate skins.  Sadly, there is no 3rd person view at this time, but otherwise there is excellent cat content throughout.

Ironic physics simulation and rogue-likes -- a dime a dozen, rarely made with any real love or polish; to combine the two would be a disaster in the making at best.

(This game was a Christmas Gift from Ashen Foxxe.  Thanks, Ashen.)

If you ever wondered what it was like to be a cat or why cats made messes, this game is for you.  Play as a cat who has some random excuses to make a mess (every time you start an adventure campaign)...only thing it doesn't mention as an excuse is being spayed or neutered. ("Where are my balls?  Those humans will pay."  "My balls are gone.  Time to make a mess.")

The moment I booted this game I fell in love with making a mess.  A simple game with a simple objective, you get points for knocking stuff onto the floor.  Starting out, it was difficult to find a way to get all the items on the floor in time.  The secret, though, is to know what the high-items are and where they're normally located.  If all else fails, just make a big mess.  That works too.

PROS:
Be a cat
Make a mess
Cameo references
Meow
Levels randomly generate objects for you to make a mess with

CONS:
Can get old (You'll find yourself busy for 15-20 minutes)
Not much variety in terms of levels (last I recall there were a total of 8-9 maps)

It's great to see that maps aren't COMPLETELY identical as the layout can change upon each boot (along with certain spawned items).  The game is currently priced at $10, which it does not feel like it's worth.  Wait for a sale before getting this one if you want your money to feel well-spent.  After a while, it will feel old.  I feel like it's run it's course at 18 hours.

20627810.review:
I love living life as a cat. See a shelf full of books? Knock 'em all on the floor. Big, expensive TV perched precariously on the edge of a table? Floor. A bunch of supermarket aisles filled with hundreds and hundreds of premium buyables? Yep, eeeeevery one of them, right on the floor. It's like I'm playing as Michael Douglas in Falling Down if he was a cat and the movie ended with him falling asleep in a cardboard box. I'm just really disappointed there were no toddlers perched up on highchairs in the game. Oh well.

In Catlateral Damage you'll play as a cat with the sole aim of knocking down a target number of items in a small handful of rooms within a certain amount of time. To begin with, your feeble, fuzzy paws will only be able to bat items ever so slightly (left or right click will do a left or right swipe while Q, E or middle mouse will jab), and you'll move kinda slowly and won't be able to jump very high, but playing with cat toys will reward you with an upgrade for one of those three attributes. And if you're particularly lucky, a random event such as catching a mouse, swatting a glowing red dot, or "moon gravity" will grant you a limited increase in abilities. By the end you'll be running at lightning speed, jumping almost the full height of a room and swatting away big, heavy objects with ease. That end actually comes pretty quickly, though, given the structure of the game.

By default there's only four stages to play through; what looks like a standard apartment, a log cabin (or possibly a summer camp?), umm, a slightly different apartment, and, uh... a really fancy apartment. There isn't really a massive amount of variety in the settings, I guess, and no additional floors to move up and down through, just a small handful of rooms where the collection of items you'll be knocking over are largely the same. But at least the actual layout of the rooms are procedurally generated so you'll never have exactly the same setup of rooms twice, for what that's worth. There's a chance that each stage may hide a collectible which will unlock an additional bonus stage (a museum, a box fort, a spooky lab or a single room decorated for Christmas) making for up to eight stages you could potentially play through in a single run. Failing to hit the target within the time limit on the default stages will end your run, while succeeding will allow you to continue to the next stage, with the overall goal being to score as many points as you can during a run. There isn't really a huge amount to it, and if I'm being honest the whole thing is pretty quick and shallow, but, damn, if I didn't have a whole lotta fun playing it.

I enjoyed the simplicity of it, and there's something incredibly cathartic (no pun intended!) about leaping around and thrashing the sh*t out of a place and not having to care about it or feel the least bit guilty. It's a sense of contented joy that comes second only to exposing yourself to random joggers in the park. But just as with waiting in the bushes for the right moment, leaping out, helicoptering a bit, then running away and finishing yourself off, by the end, I still wanted more. I'd love to see a greater sense of meaningful, permanent progression. Like... for some reason I keep thinking of Crackdown as I play this - that itch you constantly have to scratch of seeing an orb, trying to get it, not being able to jump or climb high enough, then coming back later to get it when you've become more powerful. I'd really loved to have played something like that here... but with cats.

I can imagine having an entire mansion to play with, where you start off only being able to jump small distances or knock over light objects, but as you gain more XP you grow stronger and gain new abilities. Maybe you can eventually see in the dark to explore the basement (and attic, once you can jump high enough to get in), or longer claws to scratch and damage items that were previously untouchable, as well as being able to climb special surfaces with them. Gain enough speed to eventually outrun the chain chomp-like dog guarding the tool shed, or enough height to jump up to the vents to reach other locked rooms... and so on. I know it's the easiest thing in the world to play backseat developer and say how great something would be, but that the reality is it's incredibly difficult to actually make an even remotely competent game, which is especially true if it's only a small team working with modest resources and budget. But, y'know... a guy can dream. To quote the girl in the trailer, I just want to cat, dammit!

The motivations and actions of cats had been the primary study of ancient dynastic Egypt for thousands of years. In the end they did not succeed however and their civilization fell to dust. Fast forward to present day and in all this time, what have we learned? Absolutely nothing, if you think about it. 

Schroedinger knew this. Clearly it impacted him personally, since his musings on cats was his greatest legacy. He proposed that nothing can be certain when a cat is put into a box, yet if you put a cat in a box (hardly needed for a cat will seek out a box on his own) he will simply stare at you, smugly, as though asking why you as a human have such a hard time understanding quantum theory and the nature of reality. Perhaps the cat has mastered it?

Up until now the motives of the common feline have been shrouded in mystery, but thanks to some brilliant computer programmers there might be the first advance in understanding mankind has had since before written history.

Be the cat. 

This simple philisophical proposition combined with modern computing power has given everyone the chance to take a first person glimpse into the every day life of the common house cat. It's taken thousands upon thousands of years to bring technology to the point where this is possible but now the riddle that escaped ancient Egypt might now be within OUR reach to be stroked between the ears or scratched under the chin. 

It is by no means a complete picture but a breakthrough nonetheless.

20149930.review:
Cats. An acquired taste, to be sure, but for those of us who have owned cats before, we understand there is a underlying naturalistic beauty in an animal so seemingly driven by carnal spite. 

Right? 

Lol no. Just... no. Cats are generally the worst, and if you like them, you're dead on the inside. Thankfully, that's not true if you like Catlateral Damage: that target of admiration, I could understand.

Catlateral Damage hones in on the spiteful behaviour of felines and celebrates it by creating a fun little sandbox that harkens back to the likes of Katamari Damacy. The game takes a simple idea of knocking stuff over as a cat for points and executes it well. 

I found it to be a surprisingly fun distraction. This is the perfect game for when you've had a hard day at work, and you just want to get the rage out of your system by funking up your owners' house for no good reason.

It's not super deep, and it's likely not one of longevity, but the game is fun while it lasts. Highly recommended if you see it on sale.

19383060.review:
I have found this game to be simple, but very addicting. You cause destruction as one of several different cats, most of which you have to unlock through gameplay. 

You can play in two modes, objective mode and "litterbox" mode. Objective mode is where you are given a set of objectives to complete. You do this by knocking down or destroying the indicated items. You have a time limit in which to complete the objectives. You get bonuses for certain items, as indicated in your objectives.  If you complete your objectives, you get to move on to another level, up to four levels. There are special items you can knock down to unlock bonus levels which are added in to your four basic levels. 

"Litterbox" mode is an untimed mode with no objectives. You get to take your time and explore. You get one point per item destroyed or knocked to the floor. 

You can level up your cat's abilities (Speed, Jump, Swipe) by finding upgrades. These consist of sparkling items that cats use or play with and by pawing at them, you can trigger an upgrade drop.  In objective mode, you have to decide whether or not you want to use your precious time to gather more upgrades while the clock is ticking. Sometimes it's worth it, sometimes it isn't, and you'll eventually start to figure that out.

There are collectibles and achievements, including secret achievements. I've played for over 17 hours and I still don't have everything.

It is reminiscent of Katamari Damacy. You are rushing around, causing chaos, knocking things down, and you have to get a certain number of items. It doesn't match up to Katamari in sheer variety of items and locales, or with an amazing soundtrack, but this is a much smaller scale game. It's still quite fun.

I haven't had much issue with the camera angle, and I'm pretty picky with that sort of thing. I've seen a few minor graphics glitches, but that's it. It feels fairly well polished.

I wish there was more variety in the soundtrack, but I can always turn down the music in the options and put on my own if I get tired of it.

I hope the developer releases more content for this game down the line. I'd be interested in it.

19362142.review:
[h1][b][u]Catlateral Damage Review[/u][/b][/h1]

[u]This game is a masterpiece.[/u] Nothing else comes close to it. In Catlateral Damage, one plays as a cat, with the sole task of doing exactly what cats do best: knocking stuff on the floor.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The gameplay is well done, with everything working as it should. It's a simple idea, literally all you do is walk and jump and swat. But the developers have done a fantastic job with this, the only problem is getting used to the jump height. Now, I don't know much about cats, but being able to jump more than half a metre off the ground seems like a lot to me. This means that you'll often mess up your jumps and fail to get onto ledges and tables. 

The way everything falls seems very real and is wholly satisfying. The upgrades and power-ups are useful, but really only a minor thing in the game, and the developers have avoided making the aim of the game to be getting all the upgrades, something that just wouldn't seem right in a game like this. 

The events are an extremely fun thing that just happen every so often, randomly. Things like moon gravity, or killing the little red lights, or a disco. They just make you laugh when they happen.

[u]Aim of the Game[/u]

The aim of the game is to knock everything on the floor, and to unlock cat photos. And boy, are there a lot of cat photos. 

The game is collection based, where you build a collection of items to drop on the floor. They are divided into multiple categories, such as appliances, clothes, etc.

[u]Gamemodes[/u]

There are two gamemodes; Objective mode and Litterbox mode. 

In Objective mode, you are placed into a randomly generated location, and you have to knock a set amount of items onto the floor within a time limit. 

In Litterbox mode, you go to that location again, without the time limit. The aim is to knock [b]every single item[/b] in the location onto the floor. There is no time limit, but that doesn't mean it's easy, especially in the Supermarket and Mewseum, which have several thousand objects each!

[h1]Level Design[/h1]

The levels are randomly generated, with the exceptions of the Supermarket and Mewseum. These two are the same every time, but are so big and awesome that you wouldn't notice.

The levels are well made, and you can always find some totally cat-like way of climbing up to every shelf or wardrobe. The feeling you get from succesfully parcour-ing up to the highest shelf in a room is immensly satisfactory. 

[h1]Graphics/Visuals[/h1]

The graphics are not great. They are simplistic and there are no fancy lighting effects. That is not to say it doesn't look nice, because it still does. It has it's own unique style, and I personally find that it is still aesthetically pleasing. 

The texturing and modelling on the objects is very basic, just boxes with coloured rectangles, but you can always tell what the objects are meant to be. 

[h1]Performance[/h1]

The game runs surprisingly well. I have two copies of it on two separate computers; one for myself and one for my sister. I play on a 2010 MacBook Pro with 4GB of RAM, a 2.4 GHz Core 2 Duo and an NVidia GeForce 320M. The game runs smoothly at the highest graphics settings (called Purrfect). For my other copy, I'm using a 2007 Intel iMac, with 2GB of RAM, a 2.8 GHz single-core processor and an integrated Intel graphics card. It lags on anything other than the lowest graphics setting, but runs them extremely smoothly, at roughly 35 FPS, solidly. The game will lag on occasion, but only when you're knocking around ten items into the air simultaneously (this usually only happens on bookshelfs).

[h1]Misc.[/h1]

There are many random things about this which I like, but do not, however, fit into any of the main categories.

[list]

[*] Trading Cards - everyone loves Steam Trading Cards, right?
[*] Achievments - a way to show how far you've come
[*] The 'f' key - pressing it can do three different things: [olist]
                                                                                             [*] On large objects, you bite them
                                                                                             [*] On smaller objects, you pick them up in your mouth
                                                                                             [*] Without an object, you just meow
[/olist]
[*] There are Atari 2600s - everyone's favourite games console
[/list]

[h1][b][u]THE CONCLUSION[/u][/b][/h1]

This games is fantastic for just messing around in, good for stress relief or if you're having a bad day and just can't quite complete that mission in Jedi Academy. The price of £6.99 is a bit much for what it is, though, so wait untill it's on sale to purchase it, but when it is on sale, purchase it immediately!

17897623.review:
Well, I only just started on this, as I bought it just a short time ago at random.  But I very much enjoyed what I've played of it so far, so I figured I may as well do a quick review post. 

If you dont get the drift by looking at the store page or the trailer (how could you NOT get the idea of what it's like by looking at that trailer?), you play as a cat, albeit one who is missing a few screws... well... missing more screws than, ahem, "normal" cats are missing anyway (as if cats are ever normal.... not in my experience!)... and one who is very clearly bored, as this cat has decided to SWAT ALL THE THINGS.  

Which is pretty much what you're doing; in each level, you're simply given a number of objects to knock over, and a time limit in which to do this.  Fail to clear that number, and it's game over, as you'd expect.  You're also given some specific objects to find that can give a bonus, and some that are worth extra in that particular level; the game will point these out to you each time, so make a note of that and keep an eye out for the thing.  

Everything of course is all filled with physics, which means that stuff is just going to go bouncing all over the place, exactly as you'd expect.  It's worth noting though that the objects have to hit the FLOOR to count; if they land on another piece of furniture, they dont do anything for you.  The game makes it pretty obvious when things have properly connected with the floor.

Much of the game uses procedural generation, so you cant just automatically head into a level and already know where the highest scoring spots are; that wouldnt be very interesting and I'm glad the devs didnt do that.  There are also random "events" that might happen.  You never know just what these might be.  They could help you, or just confuse.  You'll be running around, like "Oh hey, here's another book shelf, time to swat these books, swat swat swat, hahaha, swat swat swa- OH GOD DISCO WTF?!?" and there'll only be confusion remaining.  Or maybe the power in the house will go out.  Or perhaps you're told to go catch a mouse, and if you do so, you'll get a free upgrade item or even something else.  Upgrades are gotten usually by smacking around certain specific cat-related objects (like scratching posts) and will increase an attribute for your cat, like jumping or speed or whatever.  So you definitely want those.

There are also bonus levels that can be found in each of the main levels (4 main levels in one run), there's a "litterbox" mode where there's no objectives or anything and you just smack things around at your own pace, and about a bazillion cat (and dog?) photos to unlock, and who doesnt like those?  Sad, irritating little jerks, that's who doesnt like those.  There's alot of achievements to get, and many playable cats to unlock as well.


Overall, it's a very arcade-y game, since it's fast paced and scoring points is the entire, well, point of it, and it seriously feels ALOT like Katamari, actually; if you liked that series, this is definitely one to try.  Not exactly a difficult game, but as with most score-focused games, the challenge comes from scoring high; not "beating" the game.

I look forward to playing this quite a bit, it's definitely my sort of thing.

But for now, my arm hurts like heck from clicking the blasted mouse so much.  Had to do it though.  Those books wont launch themselves accross the room, after all.

I originally backed Catlateral Damage on Kickstarter and helped Greenlight it for Steam and it has not disappointed me. I remember some kinks in the early portion of the beta but it has come quite a bit of way now that we're getting closer to release  (beta until Sept. 1st as of the latest email from creator Chris Chung!). I periodically play in to see new development on the game and it has smoother swatting motions, fun challenges, and a lot more ease of movement than before. In the beginning, the motion aspect was the biggest target and then later came in meowing, additional achievements, mini challenges, litterbox mode, and the Kickstarter stretch goal levels such as the museum and grocery store. 

Thus far, I have played Objective mode, Litterbox mode, and the bonus museum level. I don't have any complaints about the game because it is certainly satisfying to swat objects onto the ground, watching some of them shatter (like dishes & vases!), getting upgrades, and the disappointed feeling that comes when you jump and fail epicly. Objective mode features a timer and a goal to destroy a number of items within a timeframe while Litterbox mode allows you to destroy items at your leisure. After each level is completed whether through timer in Objective mode or casually through Litterbox mode, you can simply click continue to be taken to a whole new house/level. I really like how each house has a different design to keep things fresh. 

As I've gotten older, I have become more of a casual gamer so I mostly play in Litterbox mode. I'd rather take my time destroying my owners' precious items than being rushed to do the job. I'm a cat, right? I'm gonna take my sassy-ass time then. The only problem I could see other people having, is the graphics, but what you see above is what you're getting. It is a simple, sometimes slightly stressful (Objective mode) game. Catlateral Damage is a fun distraction simulator essentially and I love it. 16952727.review:
As gamers we tend to gravitate towards games that engage and entertain but every so often we stumble across one that we can connect with on an emotional level. Chris Chung and Fire Hose Games have done all three of these things in the magnum opus that is Catlateral Damage. For centuries scholars have pondered over our feline friends "What do they think about while we are away" "How do they keep themselves entertained" and "Why do they hate me". Mr Chung has dug deep into the mind of the Felis Catus in search of such answers and revealed them to us throughout each unique handcrafted level "because they hate us". Perhaps it was stale water or tasteless food or maybe it was our poor choice in household furnishings, all questions become clear as you play as a simple household feline overcoming overwhelming odds... by wrecking everything in the house With tight controls and an amazing soundtrack the immersion is so "life like" you yourself will put off by stale water or a sudden change of diet. In the end you will find that these fuzzy jerks are justified when it comes to venting their rage and in many ways Catlateral Damage is more akin to "Hatred" than say Katamari Damacy. In the end what an incredible gift we have been given, the simple but complex life of a cat. 

10/10 Would Cat Again.

16946628.review:
[b]Catlateral Damage[/b] is a game that is great for resting your brain after playing too many other games or having a rough day. A bit of destruction, a bit of cats and you are in a good mood again. Purrfect. 
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

[h1]What is happening in the game:[/h1]
You are a cat, which is pretty obvious. This game is an advanced simulator of most frequent feline behavoiur: you get to throw things from shelves, closets, tables, chairs, out of wardrobes, fridges and knocking down plants. In other words, you do what cats do best.
There are a few different game modes to prevent the game from getting boring.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]A perfect relaxation. You can play sandbox mode is you want some stress to get relieved or normal mode for time-limited destruction for skill sharpening.
    [*]Apartments that you are ordered to put in mess are procedurally generated. They consist of several rooms (bedroom, living room, kitchen ...)
    [*]There are a lot of different big objects (bunk beds, wardrobes, tables) to push smaller object (pillows, coffee cups, plates, chlothes) from.
    [*]There are powerups that makes you jump, run and punch better
    [*]Random events like disco lights
    [*]You can unlock different cats (like skins) by knocking down cat pictures from the wall
    [*]Achievements for improved and a bit more meaningful gameplay
    [*]You can punch from left and right using two separate buttons
    [*]You can meow (F button)
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Apart from knocking things down, there's not really anything else you can do. Not that this game advertised that it can do anything else. Yes, there are different game modes, but they're not [i]that[/i] different.
    [*]This game is fun, yeah, but not $10 fun. Wait for at least 50% discount.
[/list]

[h1]Suggestions:[/h1]
Lower the price, that's pretty much all that can be done. This game is great when it comes to messing up an apartment and nobody expects it to do anything else. But it's really not worth that money.

[h1]The final verdict:[/h1]
Great game, great relaxation, great fun. Not very many different things to do, but the game is made well and you don't easily get bored of it. It's fun, but the price is high.

Greetings,
BirdCute

Note that my copy of this game was obtained for free for reviewing purposes. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.

"Catlateral Damage" is a nice little catual (harr harr) game for now and then. You play one of the selectable cats and make a mess in your owner's rooms. You have to throw everything on the floor - plants, pictures on walls, books, TV screens etc. - until the time runs out.
The "Litterbox" mode however gives you the time you need to vandalize in peace. Inbetween you get nice little extras like faster speed, disco atmosphere or jumping through the air like on the moon for a brief time.

The standard controls are fine, you usually play with keys and the mouse (fits since you are a cat - HARR HARR).
The entertainment factor is not so big but as I said: okay for now and then. The graphics are simple and pastel-coloured, the music is more bland, happy easy listening music, there are not many sounds (unfortunately).
What I miss is the reaction of your owners at the end of every round. You just end the level and the results appear on screen, that's it. I also see a few missed opportunities. If you as the cat can actually turn the faucet on, then why not flooding the room's floor? But things like this are just details.

So if you got a few Euros to spend you won't regret trying "Catlateral Damage". 
Just one last thing: I'm not one of the people who get sick by motion-capture movies or games but in this case I can't play much longer than 15, 20 minutes as it makes me feel a little sick in my stomach afterwards due to the graphics. 16306005.review:
More Reviews @ TheVideogameBacklog.com

Catlateral Damage is not what I was expecting when I booted it up. In all honesty, I wasn’t sure what I was expecting. Their video was pretty funny and definitely grabbed my attention. Ever wanted to be a cat and knock junk off of… well everywhere before your humans get home? Well, now there’s a simulator for that! It’s not a plain cat simulator, but it’s a cat carnage simulator for sure.

There is not much to Catlateral Damage. It’s simple premise of being a cat and knocking things off shelves pretty much describes the entirety of the game. There is an easy enough time-limit which does get a little hairy in the Museum (or Mewseum), but all things in time eh? That’s Objective Mode in a nutshell where as Litterbox Mode removes the time-limit on your destruction and lets you run rampant throughout the rooms knocking things over at your leisure. Remember to pick up the power-ups to help you knock things over with more ease!

There are also a lot of unlocks to … unlock (for lack of a better word there) if that’s your thing. You can get more cats to play as which basically gives you a different color paw to swat things with. There didn’t seem to be a stat difference so I guess it’s all up to color preference (I prefered Kratos I believe). Also, the pictures hanging off the walls are there for you to knock off and collect to keep in the out-of-game collection of funny cat pictures. It’s nice to be able to go back to and giggle at them.

Score: Meh...

Did you want a cat simulator in which you knock things off the shelves? This game will deliver. It’s a solid carnage simulator and seems to be created to just let the player have fun as a cat without breaking items in his/her own house. It’s not overly challenging and has smooth controls so it could be pretty good for kids to better their hand/eye coordination. There’s a lot of stuff to collect so if you’re a fan of collect-a-thons, you may also find a home here. Maybe it’s that it’s too simple or that I just don’t get it in its totality. Maybe I’m just looking too deep for something that the game wasn’t intended for, but I wasn’t 100% sold on this.  Catlateral Damage is well made, but I didn’t have that much fun playing it. In the end, I would say this is more niche that I would have thought and I don’t think I fit into this particular niche.

16178480.review:
Just like the animal it is named after. Catlateral Damage is simple but has its subtle nuances and charm to it. The goal is simple, knock stuff down and make a huge mess. This is something just about anybody with an inner child can relate to. There is something satisfying about swatting a pile of dishes and watching them smash against the floor and giving you an even more satisfying sound effect to go along with it. There is a sense of glee when you end up in a Meowseum and take down a 15 foot T-rex with just one swat of your paw. 
Is this a deeply complicated game? No. Is it a fun game? Yes. Last I looked that is what gaming is all about. Fun. 
With procedurally generated levels, the designs, and layouts aren't always the same. With random events and secret levels it adds an even more satisfying reason to play this game over and over again. While the game seems easy enough at first. As you get deeper the timer gets smaller and the challenges become more specific. Hunting down one specific item in large supermarket. These are the things I enjoyed most about the game. Aside from the wanton carnage. Now there is ways to improve this game. Multiplayer would've sent this games appeal through the roof for me. I own 2 cats after all and 2 cats are always better then one. Adding more kinds of random events and even more crazy scenarios to put a cat in. Perhaps a level editor or platforming challenges. These are just some ideas. Nonetheless as a game. Catlateral Damage is fun, family friendly, and full of cats!

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/Di7FWnbg3kw
I hope you enjoy!

16102315.review:
Catlateral Damage is in essence about FPS platforming, and then knocking things off shelves, beds, dressers and more, and getting things on the floor (knocking a book from the shelf to a table doesn't count, it must be on the ground). There is an option to pick things up with your mouth (X on the controller), which also doubles as your meow button, you can simply push things with your nose (i.e. walk into them) or bat at them to the side (left and right trigger) or push them forward (LB/RB) with your paws, as well as crouch (B button). Knocking a new object to the ground adds it to your "collection". You can also knock cat photos to the ground to collect them as well. Sparkling items (scratching posts, toilet paper rolls, potted plants on the ground, etc) can be batted about a few times in return for upgrades, though the upgrades do not seem permanent for each cat, sadly (future update, maybe?).

The two game modes are Objective (knock X amount of points worth of objects to the ground in Y amount of time; bonus if you knock certain objects over) and Litterbox mode (a freestyle, relaxing mode). There are also secret areas to find, such as the Supermarkat (Go "shopping" within the time limit) and Meowseum (Break a certain dollar amount of priceless artifacts and displays within a time limit).

Certain objectives (knocking over a certain amount of objects in certain modes, knocking over cat pictures, completing an objective with just your nose, playing on a "Caturday", etc) unlock new cats to play as.

All in all, a fun time, if a bit silly. Since there's no real end-state (no set story or stages) it's more of a fun time-waster, and also where the Katamari comparison breaks down. Also, you don't save progress in your Objective or Litterbox mode (it does remember how many houses you've trashed in Objective mode) so you restart at the beginning houses each time and work your way up to new random ones as you go.

Overall, lots of fun, but maybe not worth the 10 bucks it currently is priced at (dependent on your penchant for wanting to be a cat, of course).

Final note: my wife calls it "A-hole Cat Simulator", if that makes any difference.

16098061.review:
A fun little game where you get to be a cat and run around a house and knock things over. That's pretty much the whole game. You can also unlock pictures of cats and more cats to play as, although they don't make much of a difference to jumping or swatting or bashing things off shelves. 

It can be difficult to smash enough things to be able to move on to the next level, especially with the time limit, and if you knock a stack of objects over, like plates or towels, if they're still in a stack and only one touches the floor it counts as one item, you have to make the rest of the objects touch the floor too. Although a little annoying being close but not being able to move on, it's still fun. 

One thing about this game is that I find the graphics make me feel a bit sick (maybe motion sick), especially as you have to spin around a lot to be able to knock everything over and rush around to do it all in the time limit. If it wasn't for that I would probably be playing this game more, but for now, I can only seem to handle one level worth of time without feeling too unwell. 

I do however like the fact the insides of the levels, although have the same general layout, have randomised items in them, and some things are in different locations, so you're not playing the exact same thing over and over, I found more rooms on one play through and in others there were less things to smash. I can remember areas and maps quite well and can get bored if games have the same paths and places to go if they're not big games, and although there's the same basic layout of the building every time, having different objects to knock over and a different colour pallet each time helps give it a little more variety.

It's probably a good thing each level is only a few minutes, I admit if a level was longer I could see the music start to get annoying, but in short doses it's fun and catchy and adds a playful mood to the game which goes nicely with its style and colours.

Would I recommend this game? I kinda wish there was a more neutral option sometimes, I'd want to say yes and no. If you've ever wanted to knock tons of things over, look at cat pictures and be a little fluffball of [strike] destruction [/strike] fun, I'd say play the game. However, if you have problems processing things visually, can get motion sick or get dizzy easily, and want to try the game, I'd say wait for a sale first, just in case.

Catlateral Damage 是一款融合 CelShade 與九零年代風格的第一人稱搞破壞遊戲（無誤），身為一隻貓畜生，你要做的事很簡單：就是在有限的時間內盡量在家搞破壞。破壞或搞亂指定物件皆能獲得一個能力升級，例如增加跳躍力、速度等等之類的。而每一次的關卡都是隨機生成的，還會穿插諸如免費能力升級、月球重力、Disco 舞廳（？）、貓捉老鼠或捉紅點等隨機事件。在某些關卡收集特殊物件取得鑰匙還能進入特殊關卡，例如超市與博物館等。

遊戲有分為有指定時間與物品加成的一般模式與不限時間，想搞多少破壞就搞多少破壞的沙盒模式，無論哪一種模式玩法皆大同小異，搞破壞就對了，長時間玩的話可能會讓玩家感到疲憊與乏味，要是有諸如障礙賽跑等不同的模式就好了。


這遊戲推薦給：
- 貓控
- 重度貓控
- 控到沒貓你會硬不起來（Ｘ）的貓控
- 總之就是貓控
- 想搞破壞礙於現實沒膽作的人

以小品來說這遊戲值得一玩，但就像前面提及的，若你是那種想要多變玩法的玩家，那這款可能不適合你。

16074243.review:
This game lets me live out my dreams of both being a cat and knocking shit over with no repercussions whatsoever. It's perfect.

Catlateral Damage is kind of reminiscent of Katamari Damacy. Like rolling a katamari, the gameplay is simple but fun- it's oddly satisfying to swat things with your paw and watch them fall to the ground. There's a lot of different environments to play in, and the layouts never seem to be the same twice, though a lot of the same items are used. You can also play as one of about 20 different cats. I don't think your choice of cat affects your playing experience, but it's a nice choice.

You can collect power-ups to increase your speed, jump and swat power, participate in special events in the game's world for powerups or points, and collect special items to teleport you to event levels where the gameplay ranges from collecting items in a supermarket to destroying things in a museum. The low-poly aesthetic and chill soundtrack help make the game a relaxing experience.

Also, one of the collectibles is just pictures of people's cats. Which you collect by knocking over.

Best $9 I've ever spent.

16034829.review:
My paw swipes a dinner plate off the table and I peek over the edge to watch it shatter to pieces on the floor below. The humans will pay for keeping me cooped up all day! 

Catlateral Damage is a new game where you play as a bored cat wreaking havoc on the everyday objects inside the house. We all know kitten thinks of nothing but murder all day so this game is a realistic simulation of what it's like to be a cat running around the house making mischief and taking care of cat business - knocking down items on shelves and tables, opening doors, hiding in boxes and tunnels, crawling above and behind everything and making a huge mess while you're at it.

Greeting you at the main menu is a cheery jazz trio soundtrack which evolves to include some chip tune melodies and trumpets. There are two modes of play - Litterbox Mode and Objective Mode. Litterbox takes you to a level where there is no countdown timer, just tons of no-pressure fun. The objective mode has time and object objectives. The game begins with a cool camera flyaround to show off your kitty avatar and enter the first person view. The cel-shaded 3D graphics represent an array of common household items awaiting your destruction.

Use a keyboard and mouse or a game controller to look, swipe at objects, run and jump around the house. There is also a nifty meow action that can also be used to bite and pick up objects when they are close to your mouth. The tutorial shows the controls onscreen which is handy as you get your bearings. After making your first mess, in true cat fashion, you hop in a box and take a nap. At the end of the quick tutorial, you know all you need to know and are given a summary of items you have successfully toppled as well as a breakdown as to which object you favored and what types of objects you went after most.

Aside from the Cat Training tutorial, each level is a procedurally generated house so you never know what you're going to get! On my first level, a timer runs while suggesting a total of objects and a couple specific objects to find and destroy. I found it hard to focus my attack on certain objects because it was just too much fun to knock everything down! While running around a random Event popped up and gave me a Force Field. This was fun because I gave my paw a rest and just ran into objects to send them flying. When an alert showed up for a New Upgrade, I had to hunt through the house to find the right room but was again distracted when I came across a Spinner Cat toy with a ball in it. I was mesmerized as I sat there swatting at the ball than spun around in circles. This is the life! When I got back on track and found my powerup, it was a box that took a couple of smacks then revealed a Jump Increase upgrade. When time was running out, the music increased tempo and the clock started flashing. I was having so much fun I'm not sure what my objectives were. Maybe I should go back to Litterbox Mode. Time to play again!

Whether you need to vent your frustrations, assuage your OCD or just change your perspective, take some time out to attend to your cat business and play Catlateral Damage.

У вас есть котик (со временем вы открываете оных и у вас будет неплохой выбор из пушистых-мохнатых) и  создаёте хаос и разрушения в комнате своего хозяина. Крушить и ломать нужно не абы как, а на время и выполняя задания. То есть: сломали 300 предметов за 5 минут - уровень пройден. И так далее... За время игры вы, помимо открытия новых персонажей, собираете всевозможные бонусы, открываете предметы и получаете достижения. Как-то так. Суть игрового процесса довольно таки проста. Среднестатистическому игроку советовать сей продукт не буду. Скорее, порекомендую игру любителям подобного и тем, кто играл в бесплатную версию (и да, она от Steam версии  прилично отличается). В целом продукт на любителя. Причём, не смогу даже точно сказать любителя чего… Некуда деть двести с лишним рублей и охота чего-то эдакого (угарного и милого одновременно) - Catlateral Damage ваш выбор! В ином случае тратиться смысла нет…

16027980.review:
Catlateral Damage is accurate to what it says it does on it's Steam store page, and honestly, is a good stress reliever. There's something to just knocking everything all and about as a cat and causing massive chaos all over the place, even if the games variety doesn't stand up over a period of time. It's the perfect game in my mind to pick up on sale: or if you need a stress reliever right now, or ever really wanted to be a cat persay. There's some interesting elements for the genre like being able to open areas and the extra type levels like the super market, even if some of the areas are really really hard to get to. Overall, solid game that's worth taking a look at as a destresser tool. 

+:
[list]
[*] Lots of cat pictures. I mean, that's what you're here for in the end, right? 
[*] Good physics for what you want out of a game like this (not necessarily realistic, but goes to the side of fun)
[*] Objectives add variety that the game desperately needed.
[*] Love the findable missions like the supermarkat. 
[*] Randomly Generated Events keep things fresh and interesting. Particularly a fan of Moon Gravity 
[*] Like the openable cabinets and various items. 
[*] Great destresser. 
[*] Upgrades worth something. 
[/list]
-:
[list]
[*] Some Strange jumping angles in particular with multi-layered overhead cabinets that can be frustrating to get to. 
[*] While it has procedurally generated levels, they start to feel the same rather quickly in terms of basic layout.
[*] Really wish that one of the unlockable cats was a sabertooth tiger.
[*] Not really much more then knocking shit over simulator.
[*] Some reasonable bugs at times, like not being able to jump.
[/list]

For Gameplay footage and more verbal first impressions: http://youtu.be/xWp40YM1AXc

Have you ever wanted to be a cat? Do you currently want to be a cat? Stop being a liar. Yes, you want to be a cat. You want to be a cat always. You want to be a cute little jerk cat that knocks all of its people's things on the floor, and this is your dream game, because you get to do exactly that.

Catlateral Damage is the definitive first-kitten jerk cat simulator. Be the cat you've always wished you were, the one who looks at things and thinks "those need to be on the floor RIGHT NOW". Take control of the Kitten Who Loves To Break Stuff and break stuff. Forever. You will love this game, You will love being a cat. You probably already love being a cat, but how will you know for sure unless you play Catlateral Damage? So play it and confirm your best/worst fears/wishes. Be a cat. Knock stuff on the floor. Love doing it. 

This game is the best. It's so much fun being a cat and just wrecking the whole house. And the museum. And the grocery store. And everything else ever. The game is endlessly amusing. (No, really. There's a litter box mode. Play forever.) 

And if you see Morpheus in the game, say hi for me, because i know that cat in real life. He's a cool dude. Then knock his picture on the floor, because you are a cat, and this is what you do for a living!

Play this game. It is Pawesome.
